In the context of a database cluster, redundancy refers to the practice of duplicating or replicating data across multiple servers in the cluster. This is done to ensure that data remains available and accessible even in the event of hardware failure or other types of disruptions.

Redundancy can be implemented in several ways in a database cluster. One common method is to use a technique called "replication," where a primary server is designated to hold the authoritative copy of the data, and one or more secondary servers are configured to replicate the data from the primary server. This means that if the primary server fails or becomes unavailable, one of the secondary servers can take over and continue to serve data to clients.

Another common way to implement redundancy is through the use of "mirroring" or "clustering" technologies that replicate the data across multiple servers simultaneously. In this case, each server in the cluster holds a copy of the data, and any changes made to the data on one server are automatically replicated to the others.

Overall, redundancy is an important aspect of database clustering because it helps ensure that data remains available and accessible to users, even in the face of hardware failures or other disruptions.
